BC-CYC-VECSEY-COLUMN-SPI 
ARMSTRONG AT IT AGAIN, INSPIRING US TO FLY HIGHER 

   (For use by New York Times News Service clients.)  
 By LAURA VECSEY  
 c.2000 Seattle Post-Intelligencer  

   SEATTLE _ When he braved wind, rain and cold and ate up the side
of the 5,117-foot Montee d'Hautacam on Monday to claim a
four-plus-minute lead in the Tour de France that no one expects he
will yield, Lance Armstrong inspired a fellow competitor to draw a
perfect analogy.

   ``Armstrong came through like a plane at the end,'' said
Frenchman Richard Virenque about Armstrong's climb in the 10th
stage.

   Armstrong is at it again.

   The defending Tour de France champion built last year's victory
on those same steep climbs.

   Of course, maybe Armstrong knows something about himself that
other riders do not.

   ``To be afraid is a priceless education. Once you have been
scared, you know more about your frailty than most people, and I
think that changes a man,'' Armstrong wrote in his book, ``It's Not
About the Bike: My Journey Back to Life,'' written and published
this past year with sportswriter Sally Jenkins.

   If other members of the Tour de France peloton see Armstrong as
a jet engine surging through the Pyrenees, maybe they also see how
his hope has turned into fulfilled prophecy.

   Four years ago, a surgeon closed the holes in his skull after an
operation that would kill the cancerous lesions on his brain.
Armstrong joked about the titanium screws left behind to hold the
bone together:

   ``Maybe it'll make me climb better.''

   Titanium made this champion cyclist's bikes lighter and
stronger, so Armstrong figured this was a way to relate to what was
happening to him.

   In a time of terror, why not make a joke?

   Especially if it would indeed be the mountain climbs where
Armstrong would separate himself from all others in the most
grueling sporting event on Earth.

   This flash of levity is described in Armstrong's book, although
it is a book with little levity and much detail about Armstrong's
battle with cancer.

   It is worth going back to that dark place where Armstrong was.

   His story points him and anyone who reads it in a most powerful
direction _ the direction of life.

   ``For most of my life, I had operated under a simple schematic
of winning and losing, but cancer was teaching me a tolerance of
ambiguities,'' he wrote.

   Tucked between the revelations and the psychology of fighting
cancer are the harrowing details. There is the painful swelling,
the five months in which Armstrong shrugged off symptoms. There is
the spitting up of blood and the fetal position into which
chemotherapy forced him to curl.

   Rampant, ruinous cells from Armstrong's testicular cancer swept
through the cyclist's oxygen-rich bloodstream, invading his
abdomen, lungs and brain.

   At 25, one of the world's most talented, brash athletes who
thrived on the pain of his work, Armstrong faced his mortality.

   ``Each time I was more fully diagnosed, I asked my doctors
harder questions. What are my chances? I wanted to know the
numbers. My percentage was shrinking daily. Dr. Reeves told me 50
percent, `but really I was thinking 20,' he would tell me later,''
Armstrong said.

   His lessons were stunning and quick; his determination and fight
revelatory.

   ``I knew now why people fear cancer: because it is a slow and
inevitable death, it is the very definition of cynicism and loss of
spirit.

   ``So, I believed.''

   Recently, we have seen how athletic feats can inspire awe, can
turn us into entranced, transformed onlookers. The waves of
admiration and awe for Tiger Woods were understandable last month.

   That's because millions of people hack their way through a golf
course every year, coming to grips with that sport's difficulty.

   Woods' four-day, wire-to-wire mastery of the U.S. Open at Pebble
Beach seems beyond comprehension for anyone who has shanked a
5-iron off the trunk of a Douglas fir.

   Far fewer people take their place atop an 18-pound bicycle for a
2,200-mile tour of France.

   It takes years for a cyclist to mature, to build up the
endurance and strategic knowledge it takes to win. You not only
face the treachery of the 180-cyclist peloton, but also the cold
and rain, the blistering sun, the mountains and the gravel, the
fatigue and the wall of pain that shuts down upon you.

   The medical people spoke their piece last year, letting us know
in no uncertain terms what a cancer survivor like Armstrong had
accomplished by winning the Tour de France.

   Still, Armstrong continues to let us soar with him in an almost
unimaginable way.

   ``I didn't love the bike before I got sick. It was simple for
me: it was my job and I was successful at it. It was a means to an
end. But it was not something I did for pleasure or poetry. It was
my profession ... '' he said in his book.

   ``But now I not only loved the bike, I needed it. Maybe I needed
to tell myself I was still a rider, not just a cancer patient, no
matter how weak I'd become. If nothing else, it was my way of
countering the disease and regaining the control it had stripped
from me.''

   Today, Armstrong gets a rest before the Tour de France resumes
tomorrow in Carpentras. Most of us would go to the south of France
to eat, drink wine, enjoy the good life. Armstrong will be there to
``prove cancer survivors can win this race.''

   Rooting for him is easy, since he helps you remember what it
means to be alive, to surge, to soar, to fly like a plane.
